report_title: Industry at a Glance: Online Baby and Infant Apparel Sales
executive_summary: Over the five years to 2023, revenue for the Online Baby and Infant Apparel Sales industry increased significantly, aided by the e-commerce sector capturing significant market share from brick-and-mortar apparel stores as more consumers felt more comfortable shopping online. Additionally, strengthening economic conditions for much of the period, including rising consumer confidence and disposable income, continue to boost demand for industry products. However, the number of births has decreased during the period, which in turn has pushed down the number of infants and toddlers. Even so, the economic climate and strong growth in e-commerce sales have benefited the industry.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Online Baby and Infant Apparel Sales industry revenue
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Online Baby and Infant Apparel Sales industry revenue has increased at an expected CAGR of 10.1% to $4.6 billion over the past five years, including an expected 4.8% increase in 2023 alone, when profit is set to reach 4.3%.

Despite overall economic disruptions, the coronavirus benefited the industry. Social distancing regulations and the temporary closures of brick-and-mortar stores caused online sales across the retail sector to skyrocket in 2020. Even as stores reopened, consumers increasingly chose to purchase goods online to expand their product selection and find the best deal.

Over the past five years, revenue growth for this industry has far outpaced revenue growth in the Children's and Infants' Clothing Stores industry (IBISWorld report 44813). The large difference in revenue growth is indicative of the growing popularity of online shopping, much of which comes at the expense of brick-and-mortar stores.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Overcoming Industry Challenges Through Innovative Solutions
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Despite experiencing tremendous success, buyer's remorse remains an issue for online retailers more so than traditional brick-and-mortar retailers. However, industry operators soon recognized this problem and over the past five years, they have instituted various procedures to counter buyer's remorse.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Online Baby and Infant Apparel Sales industry revenue
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Online Baby and Infant Apparel Sales industry revenue is expected to increase at a CAGR of 3.5% to $5.5 billion over the five years to 2028, when profit is set to reach 5.0%.

Another factor supporting industry growth over the next five years will be the added value that consumers place on the time-saving benefits offered by this industry as their leisure time remains constrained.

Generation Y consumers will increasingly enter parenthood and increase demand for specialized baby clothing and niche products. Consumers in this demographic have a strong preference for sustainable, organic and locally made apparel.

Online baby and infant apparel retailers experience competition from brick-and-mortar stores that carry similar products. While threats from physical outlets may fade over the next five years, many of these physical retailers will enhance their customer service and provide more added value to their in-store experience to maintain their client bases.

Despite some pressure from external competition, technological change is expected to benefit the industry. Big-data analytics can be used to display specific collections of products at specific prices to specific customers. Industry operators are also extensively using more interactive smartphone-based shopping applications to increase customer ease of use.

industry_definition: Companies in this industry sell baby and infant apparel online. The industry includes online-only e-tailers as well as brick-and-mortar stores that also have an online presence.
key_trends: The popularity of online shopping is expected to continue
Differing revenue growth is indicative of online shopping's growing popularity
The industry has maintained its growth pattern
Consumers are expected to increase spending on industry products
Total industry wages are anticipated to trend in line with overall industry growth
Despite some pressure from external competition, technological change is expected to benefit the industry
Lower operating costs enables operators to generate higher profit

market_segmentation.segment_description: This segment includes consumers in the lowest and second-lowest income quintiles. Consumers in this segment tend to shop more frequently at discount department stores and other similar establishments for their baby and infant apparel needs. Additionally, individuals in these cohorts tend to be low-volume, low-quality buyers who usually purchase children's clothing on an 'as-needed' basis and rarely indulge in buying high-value designer clothing.

This segment includes consumers in the third- and fourth-lowest income quintiles. Consumers in this segment purchase baby and infant apparel on a more frequent basis as compared with households with lower incomes. However, consumers in this demographic still seek out competitive pricing and do not frequently purchase high-end baby and infant apparel.

This segment includes consumers in the highest income quintile. Consumers in this segment often seek exclusive, high-end baby apparel from designer brands. Additionally, personalization and customization options for baby apparel are highly demanded by this segment. A greater focus on quality material has also appealed to conscious high-income consumers.

products_and_services.product_description: This segment includes apparel designed for infant and baby girls. Female fashion trends tend to trickle down to children's, baby and infant apparel, making this segment more sensitive to fashion trends. Over the past five years, this segment has slightly contracted as a share of industry revenue as more industry players have tapped into the underserved market of boys' clothing.

This segment includes apparel designed for infant and baby boys. This segment has grown over the past five years as differentiated products have made their way into the market. Product- and character-based clothing has been able to make boys' clothing purchases slightly more discretionary.

This segment includes footwear, baby furniture and other baby goods including baby monitors and carriers. This segment's share of revenue has grown over the past five years due to the rising popularity of online shopping. Specifically, online sales of baby goods and furniture have increased over the past five years, increasing this segment's importance to the overall industry. Additionally, products in this category, such as furniture, tend to have higher price points than clothes, increasing this segment's share of industry revenue.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Household sentiment and personal disposable income are the primary determinants in the quantity and quality of children's and infants' clothing purchases. As the level of real household disposable income increases, purchases of children's clothing will increase since consumers have more discretionary purchasing power. Conversely, when real household disposable income decreases, demand for clothing at relatively low prices will increase; this is a significant consideration given that disposable income can either be spent or saved.

The number of internet connections helps gauge the potential market for online shopping. Over the past decade, the mounting popularity of the internet has bolstered industry growth. As the internet continues to gain popularity among all demographics and US households, consumers will increasingly turn to online stores for their baby and infant clothing needs.

business_locations.location_description: The West is the largest region by industry establishment in the United States. The region accounts for a higher share of establishments than the US population, because the West is a tech hub with many online-based companies headquartered in the area. California holds a significant share of industry establishments, with the state housing many technology companies.

The Southeast is home to the largest percentage of the US population, expanding online baby apparel retailers' potential customer base. The region is also home to many major trading ports, making it a strategic location for online baby apparel retailers that rely on imports for their products. Florida is the largest state by establishment in the Southeast.

High incomes, proximity to ports and a large population with many urban hubs attract online baby and infant apparel retailers to locate in the region. New York is the largest state by establishment within the region. New York City, specifically, is a major fashion hub. This causes there to be high demand for trendy and unique baby apparel options.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Created in 2013, the Marketplace Fairness Act shifts the burden of tax compliance from the consumers to the e-tailers.
The FLSA contains the details for the federal minimum wage. Currently, the federal minimum wage is $7.25 per hour.
Under the US Department of Labor, OSHA works to promote safe and healthful working environments.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry is in the growth stage, decreasing barriers.
Online baby and infant apparel retailers must adhere to common labor and safety laws. Additionally, designs on the apparel must adhere to any relevant patent laws.
Starting an online baby apparel store requires moderate initial investments including creating an e-commerce platform, acquiring inventory and advertising.
Industry operators can differentiate themselves by offering unique apparel and by staying up to date with the latest technology for easy consumer use.
Labor intensity is less significant for online retailers compared with traditional brick-and-mortar retailers. However, operators still need employees for customer service and other day-to-day tasks.

basis_points.basis_description: Like most retail industries, operators compete primarily based on price. Some online retailers, such as The Children's Place, offer value prices every day. Other competitors, such as Carter's Inc. look to promote products believed to be in high demand through discount sales. Shipping charges are also associated with the overall cost of the product.
Since this industry operates solely online, consumers lack the ability to physically examine products before purchase. Therefore, enterprises also compete through the presentation of their products.
The provision of after-sales service is also a basis for competition.
Online retailers face competition from traditional brick-and-mortar stores.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Low Barriers to Entry Limit Concentration
concentration_points.concentration_description: Many new players have entered the industry over the past five years due to the industry's low barriers to entry and exit, as well as its recent surge in popularity.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Larger Retailers Have a Competitive Advantage
concentration_points.concentration_description: Larger retailers and first movers in this space have benefited from acquiring loyal customers.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Profit varies depending on the price points of their products, the size and scope of their operations and contracts with upstream suppliers.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Wage costs are lower for online retailers
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wages are generally a relatively small component of online retail industries' costs and represent only 4.0% of revenue in 2023.
Purchases consist of products purchased from vendors for resale to consumers via electronic shopping websites.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Capital intensity within the Online Baby and Infant Apparel Sales industry is moderate. Most investment requirements are in the form of warehouse space, computer equipment and point-of-sale (POS) systems.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Revenue volatility for the industry is largely dependent on consumer trends, such as market acceptance of e-commerce, available leisure time and feelings of financial security.
The COVID-19 pandemic accelerated the popularity of shopping online because of social distancing regulations and temporary store closures.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Radio frequency identification (RFID) technology is being introduced to make existing supply chain processes more efficient.
The basic requirements for an electronic retailer include a website, computers and networking hardware and related software.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in one corner of the market or do you retail a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: Within this category, operators sell a diverse selection of products including tops, bottoms and outerwear.

FAQs.question: Are your sales heavily dependent on wealthy consumers or households?
FAQs.answer: Personal disposable income is the primary determinants in the quantity and quality of babies' and infants' clothing purchases; as the level of real household disposable income increases, purchases of children's clothing will rise in turn.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored acquisition opportunities in order to expand reach and reduce overhead expenses?
FAQs.answer: Although merger and acquisition activity in this industry has increased in recent years due to high levels of competition, there remains room for new entrants to carve out a market niche.

FAQs.question: Does your company lease equipment to reduce overhead costs?
FAQs.answer: Most investment requirements for industry retailers are in the form of warehouse space, computer equipment and point-of-sale systems.

FAQs.question: How does your company utilize new technology in its operations?
FAQs.answer: Technological change is expected to benefit the industry over the next five years; in particular, big-data analytics can be used to display specific collections of products at specific prices to specific customers.

FAQs.question: Does your company use radio frequency identification (RFID) technology systems to ensure that the most popular products are kept in stock?
FAQs.answer: RFID technology assists industry retailers with forecasting demand and managing inventory levels; it also provides a variety of benefits to consumers, including faster recovery of stolen items and lower prices stemming from reduced operating costs.

FAQs.question: What does your company do to remain compliant with new consumer regulations?
FAQs.answer: Other than the general labeling and consumer protection legislation applicable to all apparel retailers, specific legislation governing this industry includes the Marketplace Fairness Act 2013.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: The American Apparel and Footwear Association (AAFA) is the national trade association representing apparel, footwear and other sewn products companies, including industry retailers.

FAQs.question: How does your company compensate for cash flow seasonality?
FAQs.answer: Certain industry products are seasonal, such as outerwear and swimwear; however, cash flow is balanced out between these products because when one item is in season and generating revenue the others are not.

FAQs.question: Do you have any challenges with customers paying on time?
FAQs.answer: The majority of industry companies do not allow customers to finance their purchases and require them to pay the full amount on the spot; as a result, there are few challenges with customers paying on time.

FAQs.question: How do you keep inventory costs to a minimum? What products frequently sell out, and what products are in least demand?
How hard is it to promote your company by word-of-mouth recommendations? How many referrals do you get from satisfied clients?
Does your company provide after-sales advice to its customers? How do you reward the loyalty of repeat customers?
FAQs.answer: Operators should provide superior after-sales service, including offering refunds or exchanges and establishing new shopping platforms along with evolving technology.

FAQs.question: How can you offset the rebounding popularity of brick-and-mortar retailers? Do you have customer support services that you can augment?
FAQs.answer: Online baby and infant clothing retailers encounter competition from brick-and-mortar establishments. Physical retailers have the added benefit of enabling customers to take home their purchases with them immediately and provide knowledgeable customer service representatives to assist shoppers.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor your unique visitor traffic? How can you ensure consumers visit your storefront over other sites?
FAQs.answer: The number of internet connections helps to determine consumers' preference for online shopping. Over the past decade, the mounting popularity of the internet has bolstered industry growth. In 2023, the number of broadband connections is expected to increase.

FAQs.question: How much does your revenue depend on consumers' level of disposable income? As incomes rise, can you offer more price-premium products?
FAQs.answer: As disposable income increases, consumers become more willing to spend money on industry goods and splurge on high-end industry items. Per capita disposable income is expected to increase in 2023.
